Posts.Content: I have exactly the same, and it started 10 days after last tax treatment.  My onco yesterday said it's normal but could last up to 6 months.  I've bought some broader-toed shoes to give me some wiggle room, and my feet feel generally sensitive.  Fingers are weird too, feels like I've played too much guitar, but I haven't.  Luckily it hasn't affected my knitting too much... xxx
Posts.Title: Numb toes

Posts.Content: Hmmm, I'm starting with Docetaxel on Weds and am not particularly cheered by hearing about the side effects or the injections that go along with it.  EC was ok, and I had minimal SEs. Blood tests today were not good enough, so I go back for more tests tomorrow but I should be ok to start on Weds, apparently.  I played a gig at a local festival yesterday and felt so good!  I'm hoping SEs can be managed with good meds and I can still play at least some music. Good luck to everyone having chemo this week - each day is a step closer to the finish line... Angie x
Posts.Title: Taxotere side effects info please

Posts.Content: It's ok, Weeble, comments throughout July and August have prepared me for what to expect.  It's just more daunting now that it's this week!  Today my blood test showed that I'm not quite recovered enough for chemo on Weds so I have to go back to hospital tomorrow for another blood test.  Fingers crossed that white cells are back up to where they should be so it can all go ahead.  I'm all geared up for a day on the ward watching for allergic reactions to the Docetaxel and Herceptin. Has anyone had a radioactive isotope heart scan for Herceptin heart monitoring?  Apart from sounding like something from a sic-fi movie, what is it like? Onwards and upwards, ladies another day has almost finished. Love and hugs Angie x
Posts.Title: Taxotere side effects info please

Posts.Content: Thanks JJ, blood had to be done a 3rd time before they would release the drugs today!  So that's 4 holes in the crook of my elbow, including the isotope injection yesterday, and a hole in my thigh for Herceptin and the usual one in the back of my had for the cannula.  However, it went well in the end and I had no immediate reactions so came back with a bag of 8 drugs for pain, nausea, bowels etc plus the 5 jabs of GSCF.   I havent slept since 3.30 this morning, am just hoping I can drop off after Bake-Off! Who will leave tonight??? Thanks for al the advice and feedback here.  Love to everyone xxx
Posts.Title: Taxotere side effects info please

Posts.Content: Thanks for the info, Weeble, handy to know.  I'm so lucky in Leeds that the hospital is only 10 minutes drive from home.  Every time I go I think about people who have to travel a long way for treatment, it must be such a drag, especially for short and repetitive visits. I'm just about to go for my repeat bloods, and hopefully it will be full steam ahead for tomorrow. Have a good day, ladies xxx
Posts.Title: Taxotere side effects info please

Posts.Content: JJ you are amazing.  I hope today gives you rest and a settled belly.  I'm feeling wiped on day 4 of T, beginning to get achey and tongue feels odd.  Made it to jazz band rehearsal this morning, now sitting in bed while hubby sands down the woodwork in the lounge.  Decorating is usually my job! Have a good weekend, ladies, look for the positives and look after yourselves xxx
Posts.Title: What am I on?

Posts.Content: Keep on taking the anti-sickness and steroids as prescribed, Gaynor.  You may feel swimmy in the head for a bit, but after a few days this will go away.  I was surprised how well I felt in the 2nd and 3rd weeks, although I didn't drive in the 1st as I didn't trust my head to be alert enough.  Rest is the key, and lots and lots of water.  I hope the nausea goes away soon.  Talk to your chemo nurse if you have trouble with it, there should be something that works for you. All the very best, you will get through this. xxx
Posts.Title: First chemo treatment yesterday

Posts.Content: I totally get what you're saying, Tilly, as we all do here.  Chemo for me stopped on 5th Nov and I honestly hoped I would have a bit of hair to show off at Christmas and for my birthday just beforehand, but it's just a thin white fuzz, only visible with a light shining behind me!  I keep getting the 'you look great' and 'you look so well' comments, which are nice and well-meant, but photos show me that I look completely different from my mental image of me, even in my fantastic wig.  The weight gain is a bummer, no getting away from it, but at least hair will grow back with no effort, even if it takes a long time.  I have found that as the effects of the steroids diminish, my face has got slimmer over the last few weeks, and a pair of trousers I couldn't do up on my birthday were fine if a little snug 2 weeks later on Boxing Day.  It's hard not to be impatient, especially as the medical intervention happened so quickly and was so urgent, and the changes in our appearance are so dramatic.  I went out and bought a metallic-shimmer skirt 2 sizes above my normal size so that I had something to help me glam up for Christmas, and I love it!  My new exercise leggings and winter coat are also 2 sizes bigger than normal and I have decided it treat this 'big me' body as temporary like pregnancy and work towards getting into shape in the coming months. It's so hard not to feel as if we are being vain, but we have had a tough deal with BC, and our appearance is the most obvious sign of it. Feeling good about ourselves matters in so many ways and we have to love ourselves and be proud that we have got through some nasty procedures and treatments.   I hope you had a happy birthday, Tilly, despite feeling as you do.  I found myself feeling very emotional on my birthday, but had to keep smiling for the family or we would have all ended up in a weeping heap on the floor.  Me and my lot are not great at sharing difficult feelings but we are good at looking after each other so I did get some lovely treats and could enjoy my birthday meal with hardly any chemo taste in my mouth!
Posts.Title: I'm not 'me'

Posts.Content: All this good news, it's lovely and makes it a Super Saturday with a promise of early autumn sunshine.  I'm smiling with you xxx
Posts.Title: Good news! Mum got the all clear after surgery!

Posts.Content: Hi Lujay I had EC for 3 cycles then Docetaxel for 3.  My hospital doesn't use the F part of FEC.  It's scary at the start, stepping into the unknown, but we have all been in your shoes and can tell you that you will manage, and you will have more good days than bad, just make sure you drink lots of water and listen to your body, resting when you need to.  I was surprised to find the whole process far less bad than I had expected and feared.  It feels like a long sentence at the start, but will soon go by.  All the best to you, I hope you feel confident and calm through today and your first session. xxx
Posts.Title: Confused about type of chemotherapy for Breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi jojo I had Herceptin on its own as part of a clinical trial, 2 doses before and one just after my op.  I'll be getting it again after my first 3 EC sessions.  I had minimal effects from Herceptin, mostly a slightly dodgy stomach (anti diarrhoea meds helped this) and flaky palms, but all fine really.  It's not as much of a hit as the main chemo courses.  I was in for 6 hours on a drip for the first dose and it was my first time on the chemo ward so I knitted, read, looked about, dozed.  The time flew by! I hope all goes well for you tomorrow, one step closer to the finishing line! Angie x
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Ange  The storms were amazing!  I stayed indoors and watched from my bed.  I have found the 2nd round took longer to get over too, and felt immensely floppy from day 5 to 10, with a super-sensitive stomach that rejected my dinner on day 1 and day 9. Then day 10 I had no energy whatsoever and spent the day sleeping and sitting in bed not even reading or knitting but watching the storms... Feeling much more myself today and yesterday and helped hubby strip the lounge wallpaper for an hour.  My hair is very thin now an dI am waiting for it to disappear altogether later this week.  I don't go out without my new hat which I am very pleased with (Claire's Accessories, sale bargain!) and will get going with the wig when I visit my grand-daughter later this week. All the best to anyone having chemo this week.  One step closer to the finishing line! Angie x
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Susie Sorry to hear you are feeling so nauseous.  My team give Ondanestron as part of my cocktail, which has been brilliant at keeping nausea at bay.  I'm on my 2nd EC (don't have the F) and it's still doing the job.  I take it for 3 days after chemo, along with the steroids, and the combination seems to work for me.  After the first 3 days I didn't feel any nausea last time round.  I've been given Domperidome as a backup but haven't needed it so far. Good luck with the treatment, and I hope you find something that works for you.  You should feel pretty ok for weeks 2 and 3, I was surprised at how much I could do and even forget for a while that I am 'ill'. Angie x
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi Ange how are you getting on after shaving your head?  My hair is coming out in bigger quantities than I expected after the cold cap, and I might even shave it off before next chemo on Thursday, I'm getting fed up with it drifting around the house.  I've been feeling unusually emotional about it, having braved out everything else so far, and even made some nice headgear in case this happens.  I'm certainly not bothering with the cold cap again, so I guess this has made my mind up for me.  At least it will grow back, which is more than my poor hubby can hope for! Take care, Angie x
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: 4am is a horrible time to have cancer.  I am generally positive too, but it all comes crowding in if I wake up at that time.  I hope that the coming days will give you time to come to terms with the implications of surgery and that you are getting good support from your hospital etc.  My mum made me a project bag when I was diagnosed (she knew I'd launch into therapeutic knitting and sewing).  It's become my chemo bag, and has lots of pockets for bits and pieces.  I love it!  I hope yours sell well, Rachel, as they look lovely.   All the best.  Chemo 2 for me next Thursday. Angie x
Posts.Title: *** August Chemo Club ***

Posts.Content: Hi all I wondered if anyone has problems with muscle stiffness after chemo?  I finished Docetaxel on 5th Nov, and have started Tamoxifen, and now when I wake up the backs of my legs are stiff and my arms feel weak and stiff.  A hot bath helps, but, combined with sensitive toes and soles of feet, it's making me move like an old lady (I'm not 52 until next week!).  Does this go away?  Any eating/exercise tips that anyone can suggest would be most welcome. Thanks xxx
Posts.Title: Muscle stiffness

Posts.Content: Well, it's not just me then, Ange, but I hadn't linked it to Tamoxifen, which I've been taking for 10 days now.  I'm going to start pilates in the new year, hopefully some gentle exercises will help.  Radiotherapy is going fine for me, how about you?  The worst thing is the traffic, even though I only live 10 minutes away from the hospital.  It's a very congested road and my appointments are at rush hour in the evening.  Not fun, but I am out and back in an hour usually, so mustn't complain!  Have a good weekend, lots of love to you! xxx
Posts.Title: Muscle stiffness
